title: Concentration vs time to determine Gibbs

content.question: The graphs above represent the changes in concentration over time for the reactant and product of two separate reactions at <math alttext="25 degrees Celsius" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>25</mn><mi>°</mi><mtext>C</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>. Based on these graphs, which of the following best supports the claim that reaction 1 is thermodynamically favorable but reaction 2 is not?

choices.label: At equilibrium, for reaction 1 <math alttext="the fraction the molar concentration of the product over the molar concentration of the reactant is significantly greater than 1" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mfrac><mrow><mtext>[Product]</mtext></mrow><mrow><mtext>[Reactant]</mtext></mrow></mfrac><mo>></mo><mo>></mo><mn>1</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> and <math alttext="delta G naught of reaction is less than 0" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">Δ</mi><msub><mrow><mi>G</mi><mi>°</mi></mrow><mrow><mi>r</mi><mi>x</mi><mi>n</mi></mrow></msub><mo><</mo><mn>0</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> but for reaction 2 <math alttext="the fraction the molar concentration of the product over the molar concentration of the reactant is significantly less than 1" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mfrac><mrow><mtext>[Product]</mtext></mrow><mrow><mtext>[Reactant]</mtext></mrow></mfrac><mo><</mo><mo><</mo><mn>1</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> and <math alttext="delta G naught of reaction is greater than 0" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">Δ</mi><msub><mrow><mi>G</mi><mi>°</mi></mrow><mrow><mi>r</mi><mi>x</mi><mi>n</mi></mrow></msub><mo>></mo><mn>0</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>.

At equilibrium, for reaction 1 <math alttext="the fraction the molar concentration of the product over the molar concentration of the reactant is significantly greater than 1" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mfrac><mrow><mtext>[Product]</mtext></mrow><mrow><mtext>[Reactant]</mtext></mrow></mfrac><mo>></mo><mo>></mo><mn>1</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> and <math alttext="delta G naught of reaction is greater than 0" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">Δ</mi><msub><mrow><mi>G</mi><mi>°</mi></mrow><mrow><mi>r</mi><mi>x</mi><mi>n</mi></mrow></msub><mo>></mo><mn>0</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> but for reaction 2 <math alttext="the fraction the molar concentration of the product over the molar concentration of the reactant is significantly less than 1" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mfrac><mrow><mtext>[Product]</mtext></mrow><mrow><mtext>[Reactant]</mtext></mrow></mfrac><mo><</mo><mo><</mo><mn>1</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> and <math alttext="delta G naught of reaction is less than 0" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">Δ</mi><msub><mrow><mi>G</mi><mi>°</mi></mrow><mrow><mi>r</mi><mi>x</mi><mi>n</mi></mrow></msub><mo><</mo><mn>0</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>.

At equilibrium, for reaction 1 <math alttext="the fraction the molar concentration of the product over the molar concentration of the reactant is equal to 1" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mfrac><mrow><mtext>[Product]</mtext></mrow><mrow><mtext>[Reactant]</mtext></mrow></mfrac><mo>=</mo><mn>1</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> and <math alttext="delta G naught of reaction is equal to 0" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">Δ</mi><msub><mrow><mi>G</mi><mi>°</mi></mrow><mrow><mi>r</mi><mi>x</mi><mi>n</mi></mrow></msub><mo>=</mo><mn>0</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> but for reaction 2 <math alttext="the fraction the molar concentration of the product over the molar concentration of the reactant is significantly less than 1" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mfrac><mrow><mtext>[Product]</mtext></mrow><mrow><mtext>[Reactant]</mtext></mrow></mfrac><mo><</mo><mo><</mo><mn>1</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> and <math alttext="delta G naught of reaction is greater than 0" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">Δ</mi><msub><mrow><mi>G</mi><mi>°</mi></mrow><mrow><mi>r</mi><mi>x</mi><mi>n</mi></mrow></msub><mo>></mo><mn>0</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>.

At equilibrium, for reaction 1 <math alttext="the fraction the molar concentration of the product over the molar concentration of the reactant is significantly greater than 1" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mfrac><mrow><mtext>[Product]</mtext></mrow><mrow><mtext>[Reactant]</mtext></mrow></mfrac><mo>></mo><mo>></mo><mn>1</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> and <math alttext="delta G naught of reaction is less than 0" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">Δ</mi><msub><mrow><mi>G</mi><mi>°</mi></mrow><mrow><mi>r</mi><mi>x</mi><mi>n</mi></mrow></msub><mo><</mo><mn>0</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> but for reaction 2 <math alttext="the fraction the molar concentration of the product over the molar concentration of the reactant is equal to 0" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mfrac><mrow><mtext>[Product]</mtext></mrow><mrow><mtext>[Reactant]</mtext></mrow></mfrac><mo>=</mo><mn>0</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> and <math alttext="delta G naught of reaction is less than 0" overflow="scroll"> <mstyle> <mrow> <mi mathvariant="normal">Δ</mi> <msub> <mrow> <mi>G</mi> <mi>°</mi> </mrow> <mrow> <mi>r</mi> <mi>x</mi> <mi>n</mi> </mrow> </msub> <mo><</mo> <mn>0</mn> </mrow> </mstyle> </math>.

content.answer: At equilibrium, for reaction 1 <math alttext="the fraction the molar concentration of the product over the molar concentration of the reactant is significantly greater than 1" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mfrac><mrow><mtext>[Product]</mtext></mrow><mrow><mtext>[Reactant]</mtext></mrow></mfrac><mo>></mo><mo>></mo><mn>1</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> and <math alttext="delta G naught of reaction is less than 0" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">Δ</mi><msub><mrow><mi>G</mi><mi>°</mi></mrow><mrow><mi>r</mi><mi>x</mi><mi>n</mi></mrow></msub><mo><</mo><mn>0</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> but for reaction 2 <math alttext="the fraction the molar concentration of the product over the molar concentration of the reactant is significantly less than 1" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mfrac><mrow><mtext>[Product]</mtext></mrow><mrow><mtext>[Reactant]</mtext></mrow></mfrac><mo><</mo><mo><</mo><mn>1</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> and <math alttext="delta G naught of reaction is greater than 0" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">Δ</mi><msub><mrow><mi>G</mi><mi>°</mi></mrow><mrow><mi>r</mi><mi>x</mi><mi>n</mi></mrow></msub><mo>></mo><mn>0</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>.

skill.text: 6.D: Provide reasoning to justify a claim using chemical principles or laws, or using mathematical justification.
